Moreover,  at about the end of the second century we have a dedication by a Synephebos ( IG.  V.  i,  301 ) and one by a Kasen ( Art,  Orth.  No.  65 ) ; and in the year of Gorgippos ( c.  190 A. It would seem,  therefore,  that there was no change of any sort in the procedure of dedication in these contests that can be associated with the reign of Hadrian.  If an explanation is required for the apparent absence of dedications by Boagoi before the late Flavian era,  may we not infer that a change had taken place,  by which the leadership of the Agele passed from the Eirenes to boys of the same age as their fellow - members?  This would permit us to reconcile the statements of Xenophon and Hesychius,  the former referring to the older system ( leadership of an Eiren ) and the latter to the period after the reform ( leadership of a ndiç ).
